articles.headline: Oil Giants Loath to Follow Obama’s Green Lead
articles.snippet: The Obama administration wants to spend $150 billion to diversify energy sources by encouraging more renewable sources, but oil giants are hanging back.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration wants to spend $150 billion to diversify energy sources by encouraging more renewable sources, but oil giants are hanging back.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration wants to reduce oil consumption, increase renewable energy supplies and cut carbon dioxide emissions in the most ambitious transformation of energy policy in a generation.

articles.headline: Start-Up Gets Course in Survival
articles.snippet: How the venture capital firm Sequoia Capital guided Jive Software through some hard decisions to keep the company viable.
articles.abstract: How the venture capital firm Sequoia Capital guided Jive Software through some hard decisions to keep the company viable.
articles.lead_paragraph: In October, when Wall Street was already wallowing in the financial crisis, many in the technology industry still thought they might be insulated from the worst of it.

articles.headline: Magazines Blur Line Between Ad and Article
articles.snippet: With magazines losing advertisers, some have gone as far as putting ads on the cover, or over the cover.
articles.abstract: With magazines losing advertisers, some have gone as far as putting ads on the cover, or over the cover.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the separation between magazines’ editorial and advertising sides was once a gulf, it is now diminished to the size of a sidewalk crack.

articles.headline: Lost in the Real World, Found via Cyberspace
articles.snippet: Millions of people have published information about themselves online, improving efforts to return lost items.
articles.abstract: Millions of people have published information about themselves online, improving efforts to return lost items.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rhonda Surman and her husband were hiking around some Bronze Age ruins in western Scotland last year when they glimpsed sunlight reflecting off burnished metal. It was an Olympus digital camera, lying on the ground.

articles.headline: Iraq’s Newly Open Gays Face Scorn and Murder
articles.snippet: In a country that remains religious and conservative, the response to a gay subculture has been swift and deadly.
articles.abstract: In a country that remains religious and conservative, the response to a gay subculture has been swift and deadly.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The relative freedom of a newly democratic Iraq and the recent improvement in security have allowed a gay subculture to flourish here. The response has been swift and deadly.
articles.byline: By TIMOTHY WILLIAMS and TAREQ MAHER

articles.headline: Firm Acted as Tutor as It Sold Risky Deals to Towns
articles.snippet: Lewisburg, Tenn., like hundreds of small cities, is reeling from reliance on risky bond derivatives that went bad.
articles.abstract: Lewisburg, Tenn., like hundreds of small cities, is reeling from reliance on risky bond derivatives that went bad.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEWISBURG, Tenn.  Five years ago, this small factory town was struggling to pay the interest on a bond for new sewers. Bob Phillips, Lewisburg’s part-time mayor and full-time pharmacist, was urged by the town’s financial adviser, an investment bank named Morgan Keegan & Company, to engage in a complex financial transaction to lower interest rates.

articles.headline: They Pay for Cable, Music and Extra Bags. How About News?
articles.snippet: With the recession battering advertising online, in print and on television, media executives are contemplating a tougher trick: making the consumer pay.
articles.abstract: With the recession battering advertising online, in print and on television, media executives are contemplating a tougher trick: making the consumer pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a year ago, most media companies believed the formula for Internet success was to offer free content, build an audience and rake in advertising dollars. Now, with the recession battering advertising online, in print and on television, media executives are contemplating a tougher trick: making the consumer pay.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Tim Arango

articles.headline: Gay Rights Groups Celebrate Victories in Marriage Push
articles.snippet: Gay rights groups say that momentum from back-to-back victories on same-sex marriage in Vermont and Iowa could spill into other states.
articles.abstract: Gay rights groups say that momentum from back-to-back victories on same-sex marriage in Vermont and Iowa could spill into other states.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTPELIER, Vt.  Gay-rights groups say that momentum from back-to-back victories on same-sex marriage in Vermont and Iowa could spill into other states, particularly since at least nine other legislatures are considering measures this year to allow marriage between gay couples.

articles.headline: Muni Bonds May Face Downgrade
articles.snippet: A report from Moody’s Investors Service signaled how severely the economic downturn was affecting towns, counties and school districts across the nation.
articles.abstract: A report from Moody’s Investors Service signaled how severely the economic downturn was affecting towns, counties and school districts across the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Moody’s Investors Service assigned a negative outlook to the creditworthiness of all local governments in the United States, the agency said Tuesday, the first time it had ever issued such a blanket report on municipalities.

articles.headline: Tables Turned on Prosecution in Stevens Case
articles.snippet: A federal judge dismissed the ethics conviction of former Senator Ted Stevens after naming a special prosecutor to investigate whether the government lawyers should face criminal charges.
articles.abstract: A federal judge dismissed the ethics conviction of former Senator Ted Stevens after naming a special prosecutor to investigate whether the government lawyers should face criminal charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A federal judge dismissed the ethics conviction of former Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska on Tuesday after taking the extraordinary step of naming a special prosecutor to investigate whether the government lawyers who ran the Stevens case should themselves be prosecuted for criminal wrongdoing.
